unnormalised: The clock ticked relentlessly, mirroring the pace of my final year engineering exams. I, Rohan Sharma, stared blankly at the integral calculus problem. Prof. Mathur had warned us – "Integration by parts is a must, beta!" But right now, understanding the integral of x*sin(x) dx felt as distant as landing a rocket on Mars. I remembered a classmate, Priya, saying something about using the 'ILATE' rule. I vaguely recalled her explanation of inverse trig, logarithmic, algebraic, trig, and exponential functions to decide the order.
normalised: The clock ticked relentlessly, mirroring the pace of my final year engineering exams. I, Rohan Sharma, stared blankly at the integral calculus problem. Professor Mathur had warned us - "Integration by parts is a must, beta!" But right now, understanding the integral of x sine of x d x felt as distant as landing a rocket on Mars. I remembered a classmate, Priya, saying something about using the 'I-L-A-T-E' rule. I vaguely recalled her explanation of inverse trig, logarithmic, algebraic, trig, and exponential functions to decide the order.

unnormalised: My brain felt like it was running at 10% efficiency. We’d covered definite integrals in class, problems involving limits from say, 0 to π/2, but this…this was something else. The textbook had a section on double integrals, which seemed terrifyingly complex. I wished I had paid more attention in the earlier lectures. Perhaps I should have solved more than just the bare minimum of 5 problems per chapter! My future, and potentially my job at TCS, hinged on clearing this exam.
normalised: My brain felt like it was running at ten percent efficiency. We’d covered definite integrals in class, problems involving limits from say, zero to pi divided by two, but this…this was something else. The textbook had a section on double integrals, which seemed terrifyingly complex. I wished I had paid more attention in the earlier lectures. Perhaps I should have solved more than just the bare minimum of five problems per chapter! My future, and potentially my job at T-C-S, hinged on clearing this exam.

unnormalised: Suddenly, a faint memory surfaced – a similar problem solved during a practice session. I scrambled through my notes, a chaotic mess of formulas and scribbled diagrams. Aha! There it was – the integral of x*e^x dx. Close enough! I remembered the formula: ∫u dv = uv - ∫v du. Substituting, I managed to transform the troublesome integral into something manageable. After several attempts, filled with nervous energy and fuelled by countless cups of chai, I arrived at a solution.
normalised: Suddenly, a faint memory surfaced – a similar problem solved during a practice session. I scrambled through my notes, a chaotic mess of formulas and scribbled diagrams. Aha! There it was – the integral of x e to the power of x d x. Close enough! I remembered the formula: integral of u d v equals u v minus integral of v d u. Substituting, I managed to transform the troublesome integral into something manageable. After several attempts, filled with nervous energy and fuelled by countless cups of chai, I arrived at a solution.

unnormalised: The answer staring back at me was: -x*cos(x) + sin(x) + C. It looked…right. Prof. Mathur often emphasized checking the answer by differentiating. Differentiating this, would I get back x*sin(x)? My heart pounded as I started the reverse calculation. After what seemed like an eternity, it clicked! The derivative perfectly matched the original integrand. A wave of relief washed over me. I had conquered the integral.
normalised: The answer staring back at me was: minus x cosine of x plus sine of x plus C. It looked…right. Professor Mathur often emphasized checking the answer by differentiating. Differentiating this, would I get back x sine of x? My heart pounded as I started the reverse calculation. After what seemed like an eternity, it clicked! The derivative perfectly matched the original integrand. A wave of relief washed over me. I had conquered the integral.

unnormalised: The exam hall clock showed only 30 minutes remaining. I still had 2 long answer questions to tackle. But the victory over the integral of x*sin(x) dx had given me a much-needed boost. With renewed confidence, I attacked the remaining problems, armed with the ILATE rule and a newfound appreciation for Prof. Mathur’s persistent emphasis on the fundamentals of integral calculus. Maybe, just maybe, I would pass after all.
normalised: The exam hall clock showed only thirty minutes remaining. I still had two long answer questions to tackle. But the victory over the integral of x sine of x d x had given me a much-needed boost. With renewed confidence, I attacked the remaining problems, armed with the I-L-A-T-E rule and a newfound appreciation for Professor Mathur’s persistent emphasis on the fundamentals of integral calculus. Maybe, just maybe, I would pass after all.
